poem:
**Golden Frame**

Roll the reels,  
the sun's embrace—  
a surfboard walking,  
sand-scattered dreams.  
  
A thousand roles—  
a face lit bright,  
shadows stretched  
in Hollywood light.  
  
Silver flickers,  
unfurled stories,  
bold as the sea.  
  
Ten ways to bat—  
one heart, now still,  
holding echoes,  
screen of dreams.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Robert Redford obituary Robert Redford, who has died aged 89, was the golden boy of American cinema for more than 50 years. In one respect, with his blond good looks, he conformed to a mythic Californian stereotype, or what Dustin Hoffman called a “walking surfboard”. However, Redford managed to expand as much as he could within his limitations, once claiming: “I’m interested in playing someone who bats in 10 different ways.” Redford, who was always". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
